awd_titl_txt: Meshfree particle methods for analysis of elastic plates and shells
awd_abstract_narration:
A large number of structural components in engineering  can be classified as 
plates. Typical examples  of civil engineering structures are floor and 
foundation slabs, lock-gates, thin retaining walls, bridge decks, and slab 
bridges. Plates are also indispensable in ship building, automobile, and 
aerospace industries. The  stress resultants of a thin plate can be calculated 
through the 3-dimensional elasticity equations. However, under certain 
hypotheses, the 3-dimensional elasticity equations for a  plate  are reduced  
to the 2-dimensional equations. The Kirchhoff plate model  is well suited for  
thin  plates. However,  the governing equation for the displacement of  this 
plate model is the fourth order differential equation. The conventional finite 
element method is difficult to apply  because  of the complexity of  
constructing smooth finite elements. Furthermore, moderately thick plates have 
other difficulties such as  boundary layer problems and shear  locking 
problems. 
 
Meshless methods (in which smooth flexible approximation functions are used 
and complicated mesh generation is not necessary)  have several advantages 
over the conventional finite element method.  However,  these  methods have 
several major limitations including  the inefficiency in handling essential  
boundary conditions, large matrix condition numbers, and complexity in 
constructing partitions of unity.  Most recently, the PI invented  one of the 
most  flexible  closed form partition of unity, called the Generalized Product 
Partition of Unity.  The PI proposes to introduce  Meshfree particle methods  
by using the Generalized Product Partition of Unity,  together with new local 
approximation functions that can handle geometric boundary conditions as well  
as force boundary conditions  arising in various plate models. Furthermore, 
the PI proposes to apply  Meshfree particle  methods  to obtain highly 
accurate  stress analysis of plates and shells for design and maintenance of 
related engineering structures. 
 
The Intellectual Merit: The proposed research will greatly improve the stress 
analysis of plates, shells,  and laminated composite plates so that design and 
maintenance  of automobiles, airplanes, ships, and all other engineering 
structures related to plates and shells  may be more effective and safer.  
Moreover, without any difficulty, the proposed method is able to surgically 
make the approximation space  enriched with any type of singular function.  
The proposed method is flexible and effective in dealing with singularities 
and  it can be used for accurate prediction of crack propagation. 
 
The Broader Impacts: Results from the proposed research can be used to design 
fuel efficient automobiles, safer airplanes, ships  and new materials more 
resistant to failure. The proposed research   can also be applied to improve 
maintenance of aging airliners, bridges, ships, buildings, and numerous other 
applications where structural integrity should be closely monitored. 
Ultimately,  the  proposed research  will  have  direct impacts on the public 
safety and the environment by increasing efficiency and safety of  common 
modes of transportation and structures used everyday.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE

por.por_cntn:
A large number of structural components in engineering can be classified as plates.  Typical examples in civil engineering structures are floor and foundation slabs, lock-gates, thin retaining walls, bridge decks and slab bridges. Plates are indispensible in shipbuilding, automobile, and aerospace industries. Furthermore, the wings and a large part of the fuselage of an aircraft consist of slightly curved plate skin with array of stiffened ribs. Ship hulls, deck and its substructure are also examples of stiffened plate structures.

 The stress resultants of thin plates, such as the membrane forces, the shear forces and moments, can be calculated through the three-dimensional elasticity. Under certain hypotheses, the three-dimensional elasticity for a thin plate is reduced to a two-dimensional problem, called the Kirchhoff plate model. A limitation of this model is that the governing equation is a forth order differential equation.  To solve this equation by the Finite Element Method (FEM), it is necessary to construct continuously differentiable basis functions, which is well known as a difficult task.

The PI found one of most flexible closed form partition of unity making it easy to construct mesh-free finite element basis functions that are differentiable up to given high order. With proposed highly differentiable basis functions, the PI could have accurate solutions of forth order differential equations with various boundary conditions (that is, accurate analysis of thin plates).  Furthermore, the PI found new enrichment methods that make it possible to get an accurate analysis of cracked  plates in the framework of a new method, called Isogeometric analysis (IGA), in which users could combine design and analysis. 

The results of this project improve the stress analysis of thin plates so that design and maintenance of automobiles, airplanes, ships, and all other engineering structures related to plates may be more effective and safer.   Moreover, without any difficulty, the proposed method is able to surgically make the approximation space enriched   with any type of singular functions.   The enrichment method found through this project is flexible and effective in dealing with cracked plates and it could be used for accurate prediction of crack propagation. Results from this project could be used in design fuel-efficient automobiles, safer airplanes, ships and new materials more resistant to failure. The results of this research could also be applied to improve maintenance of aging airliners, bridges, ships, buildings, and numerous other applications where structural integrity should be closely monitored.


Last Modified: 12/17/2013
Modified by: Hae-Soo Oh

A large number of structural components in engineering can be classified as plates.  Typical examples in civil engineering structures are floor and foundation slabs, lock-gates, thin retaining walls, bridge decks and slab bridges. Plates are indispensible in shipbuilding, automobile, and aerospace industries. Furthermore, the wings and a large part of the fuselage of an aircraft consist of slightly curved plate skin with array of stiffened ribs. Ship hulls, deck and its substructure are also examples of stiffened plate structures.

Under certain hypotheses, the three-dimensional elasticity for a thin plate is reduced to a two-dimensional problem, called the Kirchhoff plate model. A limitation of this model is that the governing equation is a forth order differential equation.  To solve this equation by the Finite Element Method (FEM), it is necessary to construct continuously differentiable basis functions, which is well known as a difficult task.

The PI found one of most flexible closed form partition of unity making it easy to construct mesh-free finite element basis functions that are differentiable up to given high order. The enrichment method found through this project is flexible and effective in dealing with cracked plates and it could be used for accurate prediction of crack propagation. Results from this project could be used in design fuel-efficient automobiles, safer airplanes, ships and new materials more resistant to failure. The results of this research could also be applied to improve maintenance of aging airliners, bridges, ships, buildings, and numerous other applications where structural integrity should be closely monitored.
